Posts.Content: Jun 15, 2008 11:05PM GrammyNancy wrote: Hi Girls, I finished chemo June 26, 2007 and I have had 3 hair cuts since then (first 2 where trims and the last one was a cut).  I would say about 4 weeks out of chemo I started noticing some clear stuble.  I had course hair before chemo and now it is very fine and grey but it looks normal and has for several months.  Mine never really got curly but did get frizzy and still is in the front.  It came back very thick but it was always so.  As far as legs, pits, brows and lashes....my lashes thinned during chemo but came back quickly and are still hanging in there, lost the lashes after chemo but they too came back quickly...they have thinned but haven't lost them totally, leg hair came back after chemo very thin and then lost them again for a couple of months but they are now back with a vengenance. I am on herceptin and I've been told that it can slow hair growth and I think it has.  I will finish herceptin the end of July and I'll see if it really takes off. Girls, enjoy rubbing that peach fuzz, it seemed to change overnight for me.  Congratulations on finishing chemo!!!!! Nancy
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Nov 21, 2008 07:24PM GrammyNancy wrote: I am now a year and a half out of chemo and wish you girls smooth sailing.  I now have lots of hair so want you girls to know that it will come back.  I found using a satin pillow case helped alot during that falling out stage (I've got to say that I liked them so much I'm still using the satin pillow cases). Know that this is not easy but it is diffently doable.  I'm sending many prayers and good vibes your way.  Hugs, Nancy

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2008 06:59AM GrammyNancy wrote: I've had many long and probing discussions with my BS concerning reaccurances, causes, preventions....and I've pushed him hard.  His answer....they don't know...something in our bodies goes wrong....they don't know what and they don't know how to fix it....until they do we all will have a reaccurance and he just hopes that it will be when I'm 200.  This is the true face of BC that needs to be seen....those dealing with mets and those dealing with the wait for the other shoe to drop.  Nancy

Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2008 07:31PM GrammyNancy wrote: Hey, I had read the studies about Zometa and pre meno for prevention and talked to my onc about it as I am post meno.  He felt that it was a good idea ....when I went for my yearly bone density scan (I'm also taken an AI) the results was some loss of bone...I;m now ostepenia...and we were able to get insurance to approve Zometa.... 2xyear....I only had one day of feeling a little off, a little achy.  Yes the teeth thing is a little worrisome....but so is the possible return of cancer. Nancy

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2009 11:20AM GrammyNancy wrote: And for her beautiful daughters: Loss of Mother Poem Now that I am gone, remember me with smiles and laughter. And if you need to cry, cry with your brother or sister who walks in grief beside you. And when you need me, put your arms around anyone and give to them what you need to give to me. There are so many who need so much. I want to leave you something -- something much better than words or sounds. Look for me in the people I've known or helped in some special way. Let me live in your heart as well as in your mind. You can love me most by letting your love reach out to our loved ones, by embracing them and living in their love. Love does not die, people do. So, when all that's left of me is love, give me away as best you can. ~ Author unknown

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2009 04:55PM GrammyNancy wrote: Kathie, I too did TAC...completed in June '07.  My se's were mimimal....mine seemed to kick in about day 4 and lasted for a couple of days...mostly fatigue and just feeling weak.  Lost hair day 17 after first treatment.  BE SURE TO DRINK LOTS OF FLUIDS...I think that really helps.  I've got to say I was scared to death before my first treatment...the fear of the unknown...and there was nothing to be frightened of...I did get a port, so I just sat there...nothing unusal.  The A is a little scary...they bring it out in a big syringe...don't worry they put it in your IV tubing....you will pee red for a couple of times...this is very normal nothing to worry about. Be sure to look at the thread for tips on getting through chemo....lots of good tips. My Onc said he felt that the TAC was the best treatment at this time. Good luck to you.  You will be in my prayers.  It is tough but you will get through it. Hugs, Nancy

Posts.Content: GrammyNancy wrote: I don't know if you saw Dr. Susan Love on the Today show today....I get e-mail updates from her and wanted to pass this on if anyone is interested.          Subject:  The Army Has LaunchedFrom:  "Army of Women" <info@mailing.armyofwomen.org>Date:  Wed, October 1, 2008 1:01 pm       http://mailing.armyofwomen.org/archive/9z1za0bogi0p3dv6fbtmg3a3dr401hoo00973772rc0 The Revolutionary Army of Women Launches Today! The Love/Avon Army of Women is here! http://mailing.armyofwomen.org/rd/9z1z3ied7vmbh74oe3k5l0kd95n802lo42vj6ufsj3o The Dr. Susan Love Research Foundation and the Avon Foundation are incredibly proud to be kicking off this year's Breast Cancer Awareness Month with the launch of a movement that will change the face of breast cancer research forever: the Love/Avon Army of Women! This morning, we launched the Army of Women and its ambitious goals on The Today Show! It was an amazing experience to be on The Today Show Plaza surrounded by breast cancer survivors and advocates wearing Love/Avon Army of Women T-shirts and pendants. The energy and enthusiasm these women showed for this new initiative reverberated throughout midtown Manhattan ... and beyond. Within minutes, women were on our website joining the Army, the media were calling, and scientists were emailing us to learn more about how they can be part of this incredible partnership. As Dr. Susan Love, President of the Dr. Susan Love Research Foundation, told viewers this morning, for years she has been frustrated that very little research has focused on finding the cause of breast cancer and how to prevent it. It was clear to her that what was needed to move us beyond a cure was an initiative that would get scientists to study human tissue and real women by making it easy for them to find women who were willing to participate in their research. The Dr. Susan Love Research Foundation found the perfect partner for this big project in the Avon Foundation, a pioneer in funding breast cancer research in women. Now after a year of planning, this vision - an Army of Women - has become a reality! Our goal is to recruit one million healthy women of all ages and ethnicities, including breast cancer survivors and women who are at high risk for developing breast cancer, to take part in the breast cancer research that will move us beyond a cure ... and help us eradicate breast cancer once and for all. This is YOUR chance to be part of the research that will end breast cancer. Sign up for your sister, mother, daughter, granddaughter, best friend, and the woman you met last week. Breast cancer has been around for decades, but it does not have to be our future. We can be the generation that stops breast cancer once and for all by figuring out what causes this disease and how to prevent it! SIGN UP TODAY! http://mailing.armyofwomen.org/rd/9z1zhtjajmu5hqkcqg4bafgjci3k9nsiiahdijftgdo JOIN THE MOVEMENT TO GO BEYOND A CURE! Our goal to recruit one million women starts with one ... YOU. This email was sent by: Love/Avon Army of Women | 2811 Wilshire Blvd. | Suite 500 | Santa Monica | CA | 90403 (866) 569-0388 |  http://mailing.armyofwomen.org/f2f/9z1za0bogi0p3dv6fbtmg3a3dr401hoo00973772rc0  Attachments:  untitled-[2]      |  I'm editing to try to get all the junk off of this but I'm just not smart enough.    Dx 2/5/2007, ILC, 2cm, Stage IIB, Grade 3, 1/7 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: Need to talk Sidar rubytuesday

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2008 07:33PM GrammyNancy wrote: Have Immodium on hand for the big D. Activia yogurt is good for the big D also. Have Senekot on hand for the big C. Have some funny light movies and books. Popsycles are good to have on hand. Bendable straws are good so you can keep sipping your water while in the prone position. Be sure to have a themometer so you can keep on top of your temperature. Have crackers and light healthy snacks on hand to eat when you just don't feel like eating (it's good to eat something every couple of hours). I completed chemo in June of last year and want each of you to know that it is doable.  My prayers and thoughts are with everyone as you start your treatment. Hugs, Nancy
Posts.Title: Living on our own rock SuperMujer

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2009 02:33PM - edited Feb 1, 2009 02:34PM by GrammyNancy My DH had vocal cord cancer last year.  We did alot of research and found a doctor in Massachusetts that has done alot of research and innovative treatment for vocal cord paralysis, cancer and nodules and even rebuilding vocal cords.  He has treated many celebrates, ie: Steven Tyler (Aerosmith), Julia Andrews, Cher and many more.  My DH was treated by him and now has NO cancer...it was truly remarkable...no chemo...no radiation...just a short surgery and a couple of weeks of hoarseness.    His name:  Dr. Steven Zeitels are Massachusetts General Hospital. The web address:  http://www.massgeneral.org/voicecenter If you would like any more info please let me know. Hope this might help. Love, Nancy
